abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated unsatisfactory.
            The operation did not achieve its objective of facilitating
            to any significant degree integration of ex-combatants into
            the economic and social life of Djibouti. In aggregate the
            active number assisted (2,926) was less than the targeted
            appraisal number (3,800). A certain number of veterans were
            trained but there is no evidence they actually were employed
            (anecdotally, it appears they were not) and a small number
            of disabled were assisted. The micro grant component had to
            be cancelled after violence committed by ex-combatants in
            light of the small amount of funds set aside for it and
            charges of bias in its allocation to individuals, who tended
            to view it as a cash entitlement rather than a program to
            establish a means of livelihood. There is little evidence
            that few, if any, of the former rebels benefited at all and
            it is reported there is resentment that such benefits as
            there were accrued largely to former government troops.
            Project sustainability is unlikely: With the closing of the
            IDA credit the project unit was disbanded and staff were let
            go or reassigned elsewhere in the government. Under an
            ongoing EU program, demobilization payments continue to be
            made to veterans, but all efforts to reintegrate them
            socially and economically have ceased. There is no ongoing
            effort on the part of the government of Djibouti to continue
            the kinds of intervention foreseen under the project,
            although there is a recognition that further cost to the
            military and police force are needed. Overall Bank
            performance is rated unsatisfactory. Regular and flexible
            supervision of projects can only rarely overcome operations
            which are not adequately designed to reflect the local
            context. Borrower performance, initially unsatisfactory, was
            at project end satisfactory. It is worth emphasizing in
            particular the effective problem solving of the
            implementation team in the face of what were at times life
            threatening situations. As the international community and
            the Bank Group in particular are increasingly faced with
            difficult post conflict situations, a number of lessons from
            this experience in Djibouti are especially timely. 1) As was
            foreseen at appraisal, the lesson is that, however desirable
            it may be in principle, in the short term it is wrong to
            expect opposing sides in a civil war can be reintegrated
            simultaneously in the same community. Reintegration into
            their own ethnic (in this case) community must precede
            reintegration into a wider community. It is also important
            to treat each side in the conflict equitably. 2) post
            conflict needs to be fully part of a coherent country
            strategy in which there is focussed attention to policy
            reform. In the absence of that, while it may be possible to
            demobilize, it will not be possible to reintegrate, and
            there is no role for the Bank (demobilization can be left to
            bilateral donors). 3) Learning and Innovation Credits are an
            important tool in the Bank Group's arsenal of
            intervention. The Bank took a calculated risk in the
            operation to try to assist a disadvantaged group in
            Djibouti. The fact that it failed does not invalidate the
            usefulness of the instrument.
